metadata.title: One liner Machine learning and Deep Learning using Libra | by Ali Aryan | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: One liner Machine learning and Deep Learning using Libra
metadata.description: With the rise of machine learning, we have seen the rise of many great frameworks and libraries like sci-kit learn, Tensorflow, Pytorch. These frameworks have made it easier for users to create…

all_paragraphs: With the rise of machine learning, we have seen the rise of many great frameworks and libraries like sci-kit learn, Tensorflow, Pytorch. These frameworks have made it easier for users to create machine learning models easily. But still one needs to follow the whole procedure that includes Data preparation, Modelling, Evaluation. Data preparation contains data cleaning and pre-processing. Modeling takes in the pre-processed data and uses algorithms to predict the result. Evaluation gives us a measure of how well our algorithm is performing. Due to these libraries and frameworks, our time to write everything is reduced but still, we need to write a handful amount of code.
“Machine intelligence is the last invention that humanity will ever need to make.” -Nick Bostrom

The advancements in this field are increasing day by day with the help of amazing open source communities which gave rise to the existing frameworks. Think about a framework that does all of the above-mentioned processes in a single line. Yes, you read it right, now you can also do that. Libra is a framework that does that work for you in a single line. It’s also easy to use even for a non-technical person. Libra requires the least average number of lines to train the model.
In this blog, I will give complete guidance on how to use Libra. I will be taking different datasets for a different problem and will show you step by step approach.

I have used the Kaggle dataset for the prediction of credit card fraud. The data has already gone through the principal component analysis, so it is now reduced to less dimensional data as compared to the original one. It requires following a systematic approach while solving this problem. In the General way, you will follow the sequence mentioned in the first paragraph. But with Libra, you don’t have to worry about it.

Most of the transactions in this data are Non-Fraudulent (99.83 Percent) of the time, while Fraudulent transactions occur (0.17 percent) of the time in the dataset. Which means that the data is highly imbalanced. Let us see how well Libra preprocess the data and gives us the result.
Everything is built around the client object. You can call different queries on it and everything will be stored under the models field of the object.

We pass the location of our file in the client object and name it as newClient. Now to access various queries refer to the documentation. I am using a decision tree here. Instruction in the English language is a statement that represents the task you would like to complete. For example, predict the median house value, or please estimate the number of households. Else the instruction should correspond to a column in the dataset. Libra Automatically detects the target column but just to be sure that it select the right column, I have passed the target column name.

With just two lines of code, we acquired a score of approximately 0.99, which is the best we can get. If you check out other kernels, you would observe that only a handful of people got 0.99 accuracies, and that took them hours to preprocess the data and write code for it. In that case, libra saves you a lot of time and gives you the best result. Libra uses something known as Intelligent preprocessing so that you don’t need to preprocess the data, all by yourself.
newClient.analyze() Creates confusion matrix and ROC Curve for all classification problems. It Also calculates recall, precision, f1, and f2 score.
newClient.info() returns all the keys, representing each category of data generated for the dataset.

newClient.model() returns a dictionary of that model. It includes everything from accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score to all the preprocessing techniques. It’s more helpful for people who already know about these concepts and can code them. Non-tech users need not worry about this.
newClient.model()return a dictionary and if you want to access the model then you can directly use newClient.model()['model']

Use the below code to download Rock, paper, scissor dataset by Laurence Moroney on the colab notebook. I could have directly shown you the code for just creating CNN using Libra but instead, I thought to create an example that you can try in your colab notebook yourself for better understanding. You do not need to worry about the below code.
Use the below code to extract the downloaded files.
Us the below code to create folder and put the extracted images into it.
Below image shows you the information about the dataset.

Using the below code, you can create CNN. Data will be automatically augmented through zoom, shear, flip, and rescaling. Then the optimal image size will be chosen. You will also notice the number of images in each class and the number of classes associated with it. Finally, you will also observe the training accuracy and testing accuracy.

You can also pass read_mode hyper-parameter inside convolutional_query, in which you can specify the read mode. There are three read modes allowed. I will describe them one by one. By default read_mode=distinguisher() which automatically detects the type of data. The three read modes allowed are:
Directory consists of a ‘training_set’ and ‘testing_set’ folder both containing classification folders with images inside.[1]
Directory consists of classification folders with images inside.[1]
Directory consists of image folders and a CSV file that has an image column.[1]
I am using the spam-text-message-classification dataset for this problem.
new_client.classify_text() will classify the text that is entered inside it. In the above output, you can see that it has classified my text to be ‘ham’.
The below code will create a K means clustering model and will Identifying best centroid count and optimizing accuracy and also the optimal number of clusters.

In this section, I will be using a neural network query for classification. For this, I am using a private dataset that predicts behavior from the brain signals. Let’s check it how well does it perform on that dataset.

From the above code, you can notice that the initial number of layers that the model used is 3. Then it also tests the accuracy with a different number of layers that vary according to the performance of the former layer. It predicts the best number of layers found and it’s training and testing accuracy. It Looks like I need to gather more data for my dataset.
You can use the new_client.model()[‘model’] to access the model and can use summary() function from Keras to gain a summary of the neural network model.

Libra is a really interesting framework that is improving every day. This framework gives us an overview of how fast the field of Data Science is evolving and also gives us a glimpse of the type of changes that can be there in this field. They are also adding features for existing data scientists to modify the existing neural net and add layers like LSTM at the specified index. I’m excited by the concept that this framework brings. You can also contribute to it on Github.
